name: Alanis Morissette
religion: Morissette was raised a Catholic and now loosely adheres to Buddhism.
politicalViews: Morissette is a feminist and a liberal Democrat in her newly-adopted country of the U.S.
author: Tom Kershaw

content.text: Alanis Morissette was born and raised in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada.

content.sourceTitle: Alanis Morissette On Anger, Fame and Motherhood
content.text: Morissette was brought up Catholic.

content.sourceTitle: Alanis Morissette on fame and feminism
content.text: She has since said that her upbringing was in a "a chauvinistic, patriarchal environment"
and that the Bible is "patriarchal and sexist."

content.sourceTitle: Alanis Morissette got called names by Catholic clergy
content.text: Then, commenting on meeting the pope, she called herself a "post-Catholic."

Clearly, she's outwardly critical of Christianity, but that doesn't mean she doesn't have a sense of humor about the whole Catholic thing. She was cast as the role of God in the film, , a funny, satirical jab at Catholic mythology and tradition.
Now, she's a Buddhist

content.sourceTitle: Be Pure and Tell the Truth: Our 5 Favorite Musical Buddhists
content.text: who has traveled extensively through India, played benefit concerts for the Dalai Lama and included a song about the 8-Fold Path on her second album.
But, she says her spirituality is both beyond and within religion:

content.sourceTitle: The Hot Seat: Singer-Songwriter Alanis Morissette
content.text: The spirituality that I experience sometimes touches on religion, in that I resonate with the thread of continuity that permeates through all religions. But in terms of it being a concretized, organized part of my life, it's not. It's kind of outside of and within religion, my sense of spirit.
Angry girl politics

content.sourceTitle: Alanis Morissette Lyrics – You Oughta Know↩
content.text: Morissette is often associated with angry feminists. Much of this is probably due to her first album, , and more specifically the song, "You Oughtta Know," which angrily decries men who mistreat women.
Furthermore, she said:

content.sourceTitle: Alanis Morissette on fame and feminism
content.text: Women are so powerful they're scary, and the incentive to squash this has been going on for so long that some of us actually believe we're subordinate.
Having only become a U.S. citizen in 2005,

content.sourceTitle: Alanis Morissette's Federal Campaign Contribution Search Results
content.text: you'd think Morissette's involvement in U.S. politics would be minimal–but as early as 2001, she was contributing to U.S. politicians' campaign funds. And the politicians she supports? Democrats.

content.sourceTitle: Alanis Morissette on activism and the environment
content.text: She's no moderate either, leaning a bit left on issues like the environment

content.sourceTitle: Alanis Pays Tribute To Gay Fans On Reworked Ironic
content.text: and gay rights.
Plus, she was highly critical of the Bush administration–particularly the Iraq War.
Despite her being an obviously socially-aware and interested person, though, I still don't think she knows what "ironic" means.
